llm_processed_output.source_summary: The text discusses the Moroccan national movement between 1946 and 1952, focusing on the role of Sultan Muhammad Ibn Yusuf and the Istiqlal Party. It details the political restrictions imposed by the French protectorate, the limited development of political parties, and the Sultan's increasing role as a leader of the national movement. The text highlights the Istiqlal Party's program, its influence on different social layers, and its relationship with other parties, including the Communist Party and the Democratic Party of Independence. The article also describes the Sultan's pivotal Tanger speech in 1947, his efforts to negotiate with the French government, and the subsequent hardening of the French stance under General Juin. The text further covers the Istiqlal's efforts to gain international support, its stance on American military bases, and the social conflicts guided by the UGSCM. It also discusses the formation of a united front between Moroccan parties in 1951 and their efforts to gain international recognition, particularly from the U.N.
extracted_key_facts: Political human rights were more restricted in Morocco than in Tunisia during the period.
Political parties were not legally formed in Morocco but were tolerated to some extent, although their press was strictly controlled.
Trade unions were not allowed for Moroccans, with their interests represented by CGT, later UGSCM.
UGSCM (General Union of Moroccan Trade Unions) had 40,000 European and 20,000 Moroccan members in 1946 and kept close ties with the French trade union center.
The Istiqlal Party, among the three Maghreb countries, was the first to choose the United States of America as its international confederate and recognize the significance of the U.N.
The Istiqlal Party influenced each social layer in Moroccan society more significantly than the Communist Party or the Democratic Party of Independence (PDI).
The Istiqlal Party refused the reforms of the summer of 1947, declaring that "the first real reform will be the abolition of the Protectorate".
The Istiqlal Party supported the territorial integrity of the country and the re-establishment of the unity of the dismembered Morocco, including the Spanish Sahara.
The Istiqlal Party regarded the Sultan as the symbol of Moroccan unity and agreed on the plan to keep close relations between the independent Morocco and France.
The Istiqlal Party operated more as a movement than a party, based primarily on the merchant-bourgeoisie of cities like Fez and Rabat.
After the war, the Istiqlal Party aimed to achieve its purpose through legal frameworks, bombarding colonial authorities with petitions and memoranda.
The Istiqlal's program for 1947 stated that only the profound revision of the contract of the protectorate could be the basis of normal French-Moroccan relations.
The Istiqlal sent a memorandum to the U.N. at the end of 1947, arguing that the Moroccan nation was a coherent political system before the French arrival, making the protectorate illegal.
The PDI, led by Wazzani, collected Francophile intellectuals and struggled for the absolute independence of the country, aiming for "a political and social democracy".

In the summer of 1946, the Moroccan Communist Party (MCP) approved of national independence, the re-establishment of the territorial integrity of the country, and the formation of a national assembly.
The Istiqlal Party rejected the MCP's suggestion of establishing a National Front, viewing the MCP as not truly Moroccan.
In April 1947, Muhammed Ibn Yusuf visited Tanger, demonstrating the unity of Morocco and demanding independence.

In his speech of April 9, 1947, in Tanger, the Sultan expressed his regret for the backwardness of the country and encouraged his compatriots to learn modern techniques, expressing confidence in their political awakening and the reclaiming of their rights.
The Sultan's Tanger speech in 1947 is considered a milestone, marking his explicit joining of the forces struggling for national development and freedom.
General Alphonse Juin was appointed as resident general, restricting the activity of the nationalists and enforcing their leaders to leave the country.
The Istiqlal opened the Moroccan Informational Bureau in New York at the end of 1947.
The Istiqlal and the Sultan did not oppose American military bases because they believed "the American presence lessens a little the French pressure on us."
In 1948, Moroccan wage-workers theoretically got child bounty with certain restrictions due to efforts made by UGSCM.
In October 1950, the Sultan sent a memorandum to the President of the Republic, Vincent Auriol, demanding fundamental structural reforms.
The French response on October 31, 1950, was disappointing, leading to continued debates and struggles.
In December 1950, resident general Juin removed Istiqlal members from the hall for criticizing the protectorate, prompting the Sultan to demonstrate his approval of them.
Hajj T'Hami, the leader of the Glawi tribe, accused the Sultan of Istiqlal-communist friendship in December 1950.
In July 1951, the United States built five air bases in Morocco as part of an agreement.

On April 9, 1951, the Istiqlal and PDI, along with two Spanish Moroccan parties, signed an agreement in Tanger declaring they would not enter negotiations before the acknowledgement of the country's independence.

llm_processed_output.source_summary: This article, "The Origins and Early Development of the Union Marocaine du Travail" by Robert D. Forst, published in the International Journal of Middle East Studies in April 1976, examines the development of trade unionism in Morocco, particularly the Union Marocaine du Travail (UMT). It discusses how French syndicalism had limited influence on Moroccans before 1936, despite the Front Populaire's dahir of December 24, 1936, which granted syndical liberties to Europeans. The French Congrès Général du Travail (CGT) recruited Moroccan miners, enrolling over a thousand by the end of 1937 in Khouribga. The French administration, alarmed by Moroccan union participation, presented a dahir to Sultan Mohammed Ben Youssef to forbid Moroccans from forming unions, which he signed, viewing unions as a threat to the Makhzen's authority. However, this 1938 dahir was not strictly enforced. One of the first nationalist demands in 1934 ('plan de reformes') was the right to form trade unions. Initially, the nationalist movement, led by figures like Abderrahim Bouabid, discouraged Moroccan workers from joining the CGT due to concerns about French influence. Later, they decided to enter the CGT en masse to fight from within. The article highlights the rivalry between the World Federation of Trade Unions (WFTU) and the International Confederation of Free Trade Unions (ICFTU) in Morocco, with WFTU leaders like Monsieur Klain actively reorganizing the CGT to counter the ICFTU and the UMT. Ben Seddiq and Bouazza met with French socialist representatives on March 7 to discuss ICFTU affiliation. Abdelkader Awab and Mohammed Tibari were elected as UMT's Treasurer-General and Deputy Treasurer-General, respectively. In June 1955, the UMT's Bulletin No. a demanded the release of political detainees and the lifting of the state siege. Al-Istiqlal criticized the authorities, revealing early differences between the Union and the party. The UMT building, originally built for the CGT, was provided to the UMT by the Moroccan government, with utilities and equipment funded by public treasury. Al-Istiqlal published articles about the UMT in March 1956 and May 1957. Maroc Monde discussed modifications to the status of foreigners in Morocco in September 1957. Collective conventions and labor relations are discussed, drawing from various articles published between 1956 and 1958. An interview with Mahjoub in Al-Istiqlal, May 25, 1957, omits any mention of Istiqlal's role in the labor movement.

llm_processed_output.source_summary: This paper examines prospects for political reform in Morocco, focusing on non-Islamist reformist actors in civil society. It provides an overview of Morocco's political landscape, rooted in King Hassan II's reign starting in 1961, marked by authoritarianism despite nominal separation of powers. The king consolidated executive and legislative branches, and dissent was repressed. Support for the king was renewed in the mid-1970s due to the Western Sahara issue and the 1973 war against Israel. The Green March achieved expansion into Western Sahara. Hassan later allowed political participation, proposing the Alternance power-sharing system in 1993, leading to a socialist-led coalition government in 1996. Mohammed VI, after Hassan's death in 1999, initiated modernization efforts, including protections for women and minorities. The Makhzen, Morocco's ruling elite, controls key economic sectors. The parliament is bicameral, but the king retains significant authority. Parliamentary elections were held in 2011, but issues persist with representation and judicial independence. Numerous political parties exist, but many are seen as extensions of the palace. Key non-Islamist parties include the Party of Authenticity and Modernity (PAM), Istiqlal, RNI, and USFP, though they are seen as undemocratic. The RNI is historically close to the palace, the PPS is a socialist-nationalist party, and the MP is associated with the Amazigh. Istiqlal led Morocco’s nationalist movement in the 1950s, and the USFP has been tempered by co-optation. The PAM was founded by a confidant of Mohammed VI and represents the palace. The business community has a policy veto and complementary interests with the palace. Civil society is strong, and single-issue organizations (SIOs) address various issues. The 2011 uprisings led to constitutional reforms, but the king maintains control. The February 20 Movement (M20F) floundered due to fragmentation. Democratic development organizations, women’s rights groups, and human rights groups all play roles in Moroccan civil society. Amazigh-linked movements have varying relationships with the palace. Trade unions are politicized and affiliated with political parties. The UMT, CDT, and UGTM are the largest trade union federations. Three obstacles to deeper democratic reform are the monarchy's reluctance to delegate authority, regime co-optation of civil society, and the Islamist-secularist divide. Potential promise is found in palace-aligned parties calling for authentic democracy and local-level service implementation. Organizations like the Democracy and Modernity Collective (CDM) seek to bridge the Islamist-secular divide.

The government was characterized by nominal separation of powers, with the executive and legislative branches consolidated under the king's control.
The country was under a state of emergency from 1965 to 1970.
The Green March (date not specified in the text, but implied to be post-1973) was a settlement campaign to expand into Western Sahara.
In 1993, Hassan proposed a power-sharing system known as Alternance, where the king would appoint a prime minister from an opposition party that won a majority of parliamentary seats.
In 1996, Moroccan voters elected a majority coalition led by socialist and secular opposition parties, with the leader of the Socialist Union of Popular Forces (USFP) taking the premiership.
Mohammed VI came to power in 1999, undertaking several changes, including modernizing efforts and introducing protections for women and ethnolinguistic minorities.
The term makhzen is used to describe Morocco's ruling elite, consisting of the king, his advisors, religious scholars, and other members of government close to the palace.
Parliamentary elections were last held in 2011, moved up from 2012 in response to popular uprisings that year.
Key non-Islamist parties include the Party of Authenticity and Modernity (PAM), Istiqlal (founded in 1944 by Ahmed Balafrej), RNI, and USFP.
Istiqlal was a leader in Morocco’s nationalist movement against the French in the 1950s.
The PPS was founded in 1974 by Ali Yata, a communist leader formerly of the Moroccan Communist Party.
The MP was founded in 1958 by Mahjoubi Aherdane, an Amazigh notable.
Founded in 2008 by Fouad Ali el-Himma, Mohammed VI’s confidant, the PAM claimed fifty-five House of Representatives members “practically overnight” upon its founding.

The 2011 uprisings led to constitutional reforms, including direct election of the parliament’s lower chamber and the requirement for the king to appoint the prime minister from the political party garnering a plurality in parliament.
The UMT, a key player in Morocco’s independence movement, was founded in 1955 by Mahjoub Ben Seddiq.
The UGTM was founded in 1960 following a split within the UMT, with funds provided by the Istiqlal Party.
In 1978, the CDT was founded by the USFP as a breakaway from the UMT.

Tamaynut, or the New Association for Amazigh Arts and Culture, was founded in 1978.

llm_processed_output.source_summary: This article discusses the power struggles in Morocco following independence in 1956, focusing on the rivalry between the monarchy and the Istiqlal Party (PI), and the subsequent Rif uprising in 1958-1959. It examines how the monarchy, under Mohammed V and Prince Moulay Hassan, strategically weakened the PI by exploiting its weaknesses and creating a coalition with other parties and rural notables. The monarchy used orchestrated rebellions, including the Rif uprising, to justify military intervention and replace PI officials with loyalists. The article details the events leading to the Rif uprising, including the exploitation of local grievances, the role of figures like Abdelkrim Khatib and Mahjoubi Aherdan in creating the Mouvement Populaire (MP), and the manipulation of the funerals of ALN martyrs. The article explains how the Rif uprising was eventually suppressed by the army, led by Prince Moulay Hassan and Commander Oufkir, with significant casualties and brutal tactics against the civilian population. It concludes that the Rif uprising was a key event in the monarchy's consolidation of power, facilitated by the decline of the Istiqlal Party and support from France, rural notables, and the military.
extracted_key_facts: Following Morocco's independence in 1956, a power struggle ensued between the monarchy and the Istiqlal Party (PI).
The monarchy, led by Mohammed V and Prince Moulay Hassan, sought to weaken the PI by exploiting internal divisions and creating a coalition with other groups.
The monarchy strategically used orchestrated rebellions to justify military intervention and replace PI officials.
Prince Moulay Hassan, with the help of French and Moroccan advisors, devised a plan to instigate rebellions in rural areas to declare martial law and replace PI officials with loyal officers.
Abdelkrim Khatib and Mahjoubi Aherdan were tasked with creating the Mouvement Populaire (MP) in 1957 to represent those discontented with the PI.
The funerals of ALN martyrs, including Abbas Messaadi, were manipulated to incite anti-PI sentiment and spark unrest in the Rif region in October 2, 1958.
Following the funeral, three rebellions erupted, led by individuals associated with the MP, including Colonel Belmiloudi, Mohand Ou Haddou, and Massoud Akjouj.
The provinces of Rabat and Taza were declared military zones in October and November 1958 respectively, allowing the replacement of PI officials with military personnel.
The Rif uprising, starting in 1957, was fueled by local grievances, including economic hardship, political marginalization, and dissatisfaction with the integration process.
The uprising was marked by attacks on PI offices and authorities, as well as traditional forms of protest like boycotts and refusal to pay taxes.
In response to the escalating Rif uprising, Mohammed V intervened, appointing Ahmed Lyazidi as minister of defense and sending delegations to negotiate with Rifian representatives.
Notables in the Rif sent petitions to the palace, demanding socio-economic improvements and political reforms, including the dissolution of the PI.
The Fête du Trône was moved to Tétouan to facilitate the deployment of a large number of troops to the region in November 1958.
A dahir (decree) on public liberties was promulgated in November 1958, intended to limit freedoms and suppress opposition.
Mohammed Sallam Ameziane led an armed movement in the Rif, drawing support from former members of the Spanish Legion, the ALN, and Khattabi's army.
In December 26, 1958, a 'harka' (punitive expedition) was launched under the command of Prince Moulay Hassan and Commander Oufkir to suppress the Rif uprising.
Despite being poorly armed, Ameziane's forces inflicted several defeats on the royal army, resulting in significant casualties.
The army used aerial bombardment, artillery, and tanks to quell the uprising, causing widespread destruction and civilian casualties.
After the suppression of the uprising, Mohammed V toured the Rif in June 1959 to demonstrate his power and consolidate his control over the country.
The monarchy's consolidation of power was facilitated by the decline of the Istiqlal Party, support from France, rural notables, and the military.

llm_processed_output.source_summary: This source is a summary of an article titled "Une presse franco-marocaine de combat : la revue Maghreb et l’hebdomadaire L’Action du Peuple (1932-1937)" by Guillaume Denglos. The article examines the role of the francophone review *Maghreb*, published in Paris from July 1932 to January 1936, in attacking the policies of the Resident General of Morocco, Lucien Saint. The review, born from collaboration between an anticolonial faction of the SFIO and the "Young Moroccans" movement, is presented as the precursor to the first nationalist political party, the Moroccan Action Committee (Comité d'action marocaine), founded in December 1934. Furthermore, the article discusses *L'Action du Peuple*, the first Moroccan francophone weekly created in Fez on August 4, 1933, by Mohamed Hassan Ouazzani, and highlights the close connection between these two publications within the framework of the Maghrebi nationalist network. The interdiction of both *Maghreb* and *L'Action du Peuple* in May 1934 is seen as a symbol of the transition from rural tribal resistance to an urban political movement linked to Algerian and Tunisian counterparts.

llm_processed_output.source_summary: This article discusses the period surrounding Mauritania's independence, proclaimed in November 1960. The article mentions the competing forces vying for control in Morocco after its independence in 1956, including the Istiqlal party and the Armée de libération (AL). The Istiqlal party, along with Allal el Fassi's ideas about the "Grand Morocco," fueled the AL's actions in the Sahara, leading to attacks in northern Mauritania starting in 1957. This pressure from Morocco and internal political divisions led Mokhtar Ould Daddah to advocate for a united front, resulting in the formation of the Parti du regroupement mauritanien (PRM) in 1958. In early 1957, the AL, having gained effectiveness through local recruits, attacked Tindouf and garrisons in northern Mauritania.

The French and Spanish colonial forces organized a joint military operation named 'Ouragan' (known as 'Ecouvillon' in the French part), involving approximately 14,000 men, from February 10-24, 1958, to disorganize the AL.

The document also analyzes the powers of the King, the structure of the government (including the Prime Minister and ministers), the bicameral Parliament (Chamber of Representatives and Chamber of Councilors), the relationship between the executive and legislative branches, the organization of the judiciary, and the process for constitutional revision. It provides details about the magazine's origins in 1945 within the Grupo de Tiradores de Ifni, its evolution, financial dependence on the colonial administration, readership targeted towards the peninsular and Canary Island population, and its role as a propaganda tool for the Franco regime. The paper focuses on the magazine's coverage of the Ifni War (1957-1958), its silence surrounding the retrocession of Ifni to Morocco in 1969, and its overall discourse, which emphasized the civilizing mission of Spain while downplaying Moroccan claims and the influence of the Istiqlal party. The paper also details the magazine's counter-propaganda efforts against Moroccan media, its internal structure, and its ultimate failure to adapt to changing political realities, leading to its discontinuation. It also describes the Francoist regime's efforts to develop media in Ifni and Sahara to counter the Istiqlal party's expansionist ideas. The analysis reveals the magazine's role in promoting a pro-Spanish narrative and its selective reporting, designed to maintain the status quo of Spanish colonial rule.
extracted_key_facts: The A.O.E. weekly magazine was established in Ifni on April 15, 1945, by José Bermejo López, governor general of A.O.E., and directed by Alfonso Beriso Lardín.
The magazine was linked to the Grupo de Tiradores de Ifni.
The magazine was financially dependent on the colonial administration, with only a quarter of its costs covered by advertising, sales, and subscriptions.
The magazine primarily targeted the peninsular and Canary Island population residing in Ifni.
From 1956, the Istiqlal party, led by Allal El Fassi, advocated for the annexation of Ifni, Tarfaya, and Western Sahara to Morocco.
The Ejército de Liberación (Army of Liberation), supported by Morocco, infiltrated Ifni and Sahara starting in 1956.
On November 23, 1957, armed bands attacked Spanish military presence in Ifni, marking the start of the Ifni War.
On January 10, 1958, Ifni and Sahara were declared Spanish provinces.
On April 10, 1958, Spain ceded Tarfaya to Morocco in exchange for maintaining the status quo in the region.
In 1969, Ifni was retroceded to Morocco.
The A.O.E. magazine ceased publication on December 31, 1968, before the official retrocession of Ifni to Morocco.

The A.O.E. magazine's coverage of the 1957-1958 war was limited to publishing favorable military reports and official declarations, avoiding details on the conflict's true evolution and international implications.
The Franco regime developed media in A.O.E. to gain support from the indigenous population and reinforce the peninsular and Canarian population.
The Istiqlal party sought to gain the adherence of Ifni and Sahrawi people to its expansionist ideas.
The A.O.E. magazine presented a narrative emphasizing Spain's 'civilizing' work in Ifni and countering the claims of the 'Gran Marruecos'.
The magazine attempted to legitimize Spanish presence in Ifni by referencing historical ties and treaties, including the 1860 treaty with Morocco and the 1934 occupation by Colonel Capaz.
A.O.E. downplayed the participation of the Ait Ba Amran in the Ejército de Liberación during the Ifni War, presenting them instead as victims.
The magazine engaged in counterpropaganda efforts, discrediting Moroccan media and dismissing the territorial claims of Allal El Fassi.
After the independence of the Spanish protectorate in Morocco in 1956, the Istiqlal party claimed the territories of Tarfaya, Ifni, and Western Sahara as part of 'Greater Morocco'.

llm_processed_output.source_summary: This GIGA Focus paper by Merouan Mekouar (June 2018) examines the politics of elite co-optation in Morocco under King Mohamed VI, focusing on how neo-liberal reforms have been used to strengthen the monarchy's power and consolidate its alliance with economic and political elites since 1999. The paper argues that while these policies have benefited the elite, they have also led to increased inequality and discontent, potentially destabilizing the country and creating challenges for European security. It highlights the king's strategy of offering policy concessions and actively co-opting potential challengers by granting them access to state resources, expanding on the approaches of previous Moroccan kings, Mohamed V and Hassan II. The study details the mechanisms of economic co-optation, including privatization, public-private partnerships, and bureaucratic duplicity, which have allowed the monarchy and its associates to accumulate wealth and maintain control. The paper concludes by discussing the implications of this system for social and political stability in Morocco and suggests that the EU should push for genuine democratic reforms and respect for human rights.

The neo-liberal turn in Morocco has increased inequality and weakened formal political participation channels.
Elite opposition, rather than mass opposition, is considered the most serious political danger by the Moroccan palace.
Moroccan kings since independence in 1956 have used policy concessions and elite co-optation to pre-empt mobilization.
Mohamed V used rent channels to reward loyalist rural elites for their support during his struggle with nationalists.
Hassan II used the same strategy as Mohamed V to reward loyalist leftist parties who supported his marginalization of Islamic movements.
Since 1999, Mohamed VI has overseen large-scale neo-liberal reforms which have created new opportunities for economic co-optation.

Neo-liberal policies in the form of privatization, liberalization, and administrative deregulation served a double function of freeing the authorities from financial burden and producing a new generation of business elites dependent on the state.
By 2008, 90 of Morocco’s biggest public companies were partially or fully privatised, with the most profitable ones privatised before 2005.
Bureaucratic duplicity mobilizes state resources to protect specific commercial enterprises labeled “national champions.”
The Plan Vert project is an agricultural project where land was made available below market price to private actors close to the regime.

Prices have been liberalized in the gas sector without concomitant state control, resulting in the sector being managed by only 15 actors, one of whom, Aziz Akhannouch, controls roughly 30 percent of the market and is also the minister of agriculture.
A 2017 study showed that after the king and his family, the second-biggest beneficiaries of privatization and liberalization policies were 150 families close to the monarchy.
During the 2011 Arab uprisings, additional revenues allowed the regime to buy key constituencies.
Moroccan media figures are generally members of either the regime or the local bourgeoisie, according to a 2017 analysis.
Constitutional and administrative reforms have been used to depoliticize and bureaucratize former opponents by rewarding them with salaries and public status.
Examples of mediation instances created under royal impulse include the Human Rights National Council (CNDH) and the Council for Moroccans Residing Abroad (CCME).
The Mohamed V Foundation for Solidarity and the Hassan II Fund for Economic and Social Solidarity benefit from significant public resources and fall under the authority of the king's entourage.
Corruption is seen as a deliberate choice to encourage criminal practices.

The withdrawal of the state in what one journalist calls “useful Morocco” has caused protests in rural or semi-rural areas, such as the Rif region (2017 and 2018) and the mining city of Jerada (2018).
Morocco's privatization of state-owned institutions, land, and culture has consolidated the politico-economic pact between the monarchy and the elite.
Drug seizures have increased in all categories since 2013, with more than 2.8 tonnes of cocaine seized in one year in Casablanca alone.
A commercial boycott campaign launched online in May 2018 targeted companies accused of setting prices out of reach for the majority of the population.

extracted_key_facts: The Ifni-Sahara conflict took place in 1957-58, with around 800 Spanish casualties.

In 1946, Ifni and the Western Sahara were integrated into a single political and military entity: the Spanish West Africa (AOE).
In 1956, the AOE comprised the enclave of Ifni, the southern zone of the Spanish protectorate in Morocco (Tarfaya strip), and the Spanish Sahara.
After Morocco's independence in 1956, armed bands of the Army of Liberation (linked to Istiqlal party) moved south, infiltrating Ifni and the Spanish Sahara.
By October 1956, these bands had infiltrated the Spanish Sahara, reaching Villa Cisneros, and numbered over 3,000 men with portable weaponry.
A merchant from Sidi Ifni named Boaia, residing in Rabat, was a major supplier to these bands and was later appointed governor of Tarfaya by Mohamed V.
In March 1956, the Spanish Navy corvettes and minador Neptuno established coastal surveillance to prevent clandestine landings of men and arms.
The 1st Paratrooper Bandera and the 13th Legion Bandera were sent to AOE as reinforcements in May-June 1956.
The 'Europeanization' of indigenous Tiradores de Ifni units occurred, replacing indigenous soldiers with Spanish conscripts.
The Brigada de Marinería de Ifni, composed of 100 sailors and a contramaestre, was created in June 1956 to assist with unloading ships at Sidi Ifni beach.

By early 1957, the Spanish government Madrid, pursued a policy of 'habilidad y tacto diplomático', effectively turning a blind eye to the armed bands which led to the loss of prestige among the Saharawi population.
In January 1957, the 1st Paratrooper Bandera was replaced by the 2nd, revealing logistical difficulties due to the lack of a port in Sidi Ifni and inadequate landing resources.
In February 1957, armed bands in the Spanish Sahara clashed heavily with French forces south of Tifariti.
On February 25, 1957, a change in government occurred, but the policy of restricted defense spending continued.

On March 21, 1957, Admiral Carrero Blanco instructed the governor of AOE, General Pardo de Santayana, to disarm weak parties of the bands, avoid armed clashes with strong ones, and inform the French if their actions targeted them.
The first military priority was motorizing Saharan units, requiring barcazas K to transport trucks and jeeps to El Aaiún and Villa Cisneros.
On June 17, 1957, the cruiser Méndez Núñez and transport Tarifa sailed from Ceuta with the 4th Legion Bandera, landing in Villa Cisneros on June 21.

In June 1957, the new Governor General of AOE, General Zamalloa, was ordered to abandon inland posts in the Spanish Sahara and concentrate forces in four points: Villa Bens, El Aaiún, Villa Cisneros-El Aargú, and La Güera.
On July 27, 1957, the Junta de Defensa Nacional in Madrid decided to expel the armed bands from the Sahara, reversing the previous policy.

The Spanish Armada recommended delaying any attack until sufficient transport and landing resources were available and began mobilizing merchant ships and seeking amphibious assistance from the US and French navies.
The plan involved two Spanish motorized columns departing from Villa Bens and El Aaiún to clear the Saguia El Hamra, converging at Smara with French forces and a paratrooper drop.

The Agrupación 'A' was made up of the cruisers Canarias, Méndez Núñez and the destroyers Churruca, Gravina and José Luis Díez, and Agrupación 'B', by the cruisers Cervantes and Cervera and the destroyers Miranda, Antequera, Jorge Juan and Escaño.

llm_processed_output.source_summary: This document provides a historical overview of the relationship between Spain and Morocco, beginning with the Reconquista and continuing through the decolonization of the Sahara. It covers key events like the capture of Melilla (1497), the Spanish protectorate in Morocco (established formally in 1912 after the Treaty of Fez and the Madrid Treaty), the Rif War (1921-1927), the Ifni War (late 1950s), and the Green March (1975). It discusses Moroccan independence in 1956 and the subsequent disputes over territories like Tarfaya, Sidi Ifni and the Western Sahara. The text also touches on the formation of the Frente Polisario and its impact on the political landscape, focusing on the struggle for the independence of Western Sahara, and the various conflicts and agreements between Spain and Morocco regarding fishing rights, territorial claims, and migration. The analysis extends to the Perejil Island crisis in 2002, highlighting the ongoing tensions and territorial disputes between the two countries. The document also mentions the rise of Moroccan independence movements in the 1930s and 1940s, fueled by Istiqlal and supported by the Arab world, leading to the exile and later return of King Mohamed V. The text emphasizes the interwoven relationship between the colonial history of Spain in Morocco and the rise of Moroccan nationalism and independence movements. It concludes by reflecting on the complex dynamics of the current relationship, highlighting both cooperation and unresolved issues.
extracted_key_facts: Melilla was captured by Spain in 1497.
The Spanish protectorate in Morocco was officially recognized in the Treaty of Madrid in 1912, based on the Treaty of Fez signed earlier that year.
The Rif War, starting with Abd el-Krim's uprising in 1921 and the "Desastre de Annual", weakened the Spanish regime and contributed to Primo de Rivera's coup in 1923.
The Spanish protectorate included the Rif and Tebala regions in the north and Tarfaya in the south, later expanded to include Sidi-Ifni and Río de Oro.
Independentist movements, backed by much of the Arab world, germinated in the 1930s and 1940s.
The Istiqlal movement gained momentum, contributing to Moroccan independence aspirations.
King Mohamed V was exiled in 1953 and then returned in 1955, becoming a symbol of independence.
France unilaterally ended the Franco-Spanish protectorate in March 1956.
Spain recognized the independence of Morocco on April 5, 1956, ratified in the Hispano-Moroccan treaty on April 7.
After independence in 1956, the new kingdom gained the Rif region; Trafaya (Cabo Juby), Sidi-Ifni, and the Western Sahara remained disputed.
The “Ejército de Liberación” (armed branch of Istiqlal) was used to harass Spanish territories after 1956.
The Ifni War (an undeclared war) began in November 1957.
The Treaty of Cintra, April 1, 1958, ceded the region of Cabo Juby, including Villa-Bens (Tarfaya) and Tan-Tan to Morocco.
Spain ceded Sidi-Ifni to Morocco in the Treaty of Retrocession of Ifni and Anejos, on January 4, 1969.
In 1965, the UN General Assembly urged Spain to 'decolonize' the territories of Western Sahara.
The Frente Polisario was created on May 10, 1973, with El Gali as secretary general, advocating for the independence of Western Sahara.
The Green March, initiated by King Hassan II in late October 1975, resulted in Morocco's occupation of the Western Sahara.
The Madrid Agreement of November 9 led to Spain's withdrawal and the division of Western Sahara between Morocco and Mauritania.
Spain completed the cession of the Sahara on January 12, 1976, with the withdrawal of the last contingent of legionnaires.
After the Green March, Spain focused on maintaining the security of Ceuta and Melilla.
There were attacks on Spanish fishing boats by the Polisario Front between 1977 and 1986, resulting in 289 Spanish victims.
The Perejil Island crisis occurred on July 11, 2002, when Moroccan forces occupied the island, leading to a Spanish military response.
Morocco has repeatedly claimed Ceuta and Melilla, likening their status to Gibraltar.
